content.description: Right-most line on the first cliff you come to.  Climb up to a fixed pin under a roof, traverse right, and slab past 2 more bolts to the shared 2-bolt anchor.  A good smearing warm-up and/or way to set a toprope on the harder two to its left.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a fixed pin.  You might place another piece or two but you probably don't need it.
content.location: Right most line on the first cliff with routes on it.

content.description: An interesting slab climb following bolts on the upper (left) formation at the Lower La Cueva Domes.  Worthwhile.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor. You might also place a finger-size cam.Anchor would benefit from new cord/quicklinks etc, but I survived.
content.location: Marco Bolto (and Classic Ramp) are about 100' left and uphill of the 3 other routes in the Lower La Cueva Domes.  Marco Bolto is the bolted line.

climbs.name: Leonardo Da Smeari
climbs.fa: Wayne Taylor. FFA Paul Horak, Kathy Kocon, Mark Leonard, 1985

content.description: On the first black water-streaked formation you come to hiking up the gully.  The line headed up a seam to a piton on the left side of this cliff.  Crux passing the first bolt, I thought.  You'll see the fixed pin where the crack jogs right.  There's one bolt above this that leads you to the anchor.  Fun slabbing while trying to make use of the seam; the traverse right along the diagonal crack was also neat.  First bolts kind of high, you might get some tiny gear in on your way to it.  Climbing this one reminded me to be impressed by a previous generation of Sandia climbers.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a fixed pin; 2-bolt anchor shared with Blank Canvas and Mona Feetsa. You might sneak in some small nuts or RPs, maybe even some tiny cams.
content.location: Left-most route of the first black streaked cliff.  Look for a bolt at about 12' and a fixed pin higher where the crack jogs to the right.

content.description: Right of Marco Bolto, on the left "dome" formation.  Start by angling right from the start of Marco Bolto, passing the left side of a low roof, and looking up at the left end of a second roof.  There's a bolt above this to turn it directly (I didnt' go this way), but the way I went and the guidebooks suggest is to angle right under the second roof, then go up easier but runout terrain, then walk left on bushy ledges to the 2-bolt anchor, shared with Marco Bolto.  Kind of wandery and discontinuous, but the easiest climb at the area.
content.location: Just right of Marco Bolto on the left of the two slab cliffs at the area.

content.description: Tricky thin slabbing up the center line.  Crux seemed to be just past the 2nd bolt; then it joins Leonardo Da Smeari above the diagonal crack.  A great climb to see what you can stand on. If it was longer it would be a legitimate testpiece; this still may be the hardest decently-protected slab pitch in Lower La Cueva Canyon.  Kind of high first bolt but if you can't get there you don't have a chance.  Old guidebook to the Sandia foothills called this "Christopher Columbogus"... Blank Canvas is more elegant and apt.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor shared with the other routes. Possibly a nut into the diagonal crack - you'll have probably lowered past this after climbing one of the other routes to know for sure if that's something you want.
content.location: Center route on the first black-streaked cliff.

content.description: A couple of outcrops with water polished slab climbing high up on the south side as you enter La Cueva Canyon. Think minor South Platte domes, rather than giant Tuolumne/Sierra domes, and you might appreciate the area for the slab technique climbing practice it can provide.  North-facing and probably shaded nearly all the time.
